I feel like no one really learned from the failure of Tidal.This app is gonna fail miserably, let’s be honest with ourselves. The views on these videos are all terrible compared to what they get on YouTube, and yes I’m aware the app is just starting out, but with as much exposure as it’s getting, for these big creators to only be a few hundred views, and considering that this probably the most exposure the app will ever get, it’s not looking sustainable.The creators of StoryFire made a huge mistake by marketing themselves to video creators instead of marketing to audiences. Yes they’ll get big names to join their platform, but it won’t mean much if nobody’s logging onto their app. Audiences aren’t going to switch to a worse version of youtube just so their favorite content creators can get a bigger paycheck, they just want to see content in a way that’s easily assessable, and you’ve got to market yourself in a way that offers something to viewers that youtube doesn’t. “What about exclusive videos from their favorite creators?” Tidal tried that already and it didn’t work because as soon as they heard Kanye West & Beyoncé’s new albums, they went right back to spotify and Apple Music. The audiences didn’t have any incentive to stay with tidal, and they preferred the other streaming services.Despite all of its flaws, YouTube is an amazing platform for the viewer, there’s nothing that StoryFire offers that youtube doesn’t already do 10 times better. You could argue the “twitter like features” But youtube already has comments and the community tab which fulfill essentially  the same needs. Given the choice of storyfire or youtube, over 99% of viewers are gonna watch on YouTube, because it’s simply a better platform for the consumer (audience members/video watchers) and creators are eventually gonna realize that they need to stop putting so much effort into a platform very few people outside of content creators themselves actually care about.I think you all are falling into this delusion that this’ll be successful simply because you because you’re sick of all of YouTube’s issues with demonetization (and rightfully so) which means you’re desperate to find any kind of alternative that doesn’t have those issues.Overall, it’s gonna be a nice lil fad that fades out in a few months. Give your opinion on the subject matter.

TJump did a good job of getting to the heart of  the problem—that this hypothesis is indistinguishable from any God hypothesis, or any other unfounded ontological speculation, but he had to be patient to get there and there was no answer to that problem from Goff, he’s carrying an empty sack. How could you tell the difference between consciousness at the atomic level that’s both untestable/untraceable (fundamental) and actually exists [ie that’s real] and consciousness at the atomic level that is untestable/untraceable (fundamental), but that doesn’t actually exist [that’s imaginary]? Empty sack.It seems that if X is the gap in the physicalist explanation, the panpsychist answer to the question of how our consciousness emerges is: Matter + X = Biological Consciousness, where X = Fundamental Consciousness. Does his distinction between Biological and Fundamental suggest a possible equivocation on “consciousness”? Are they different in kind or degree? If degree, why would complex biological relations be necessary and not merely material density to produce consciousness?  Is life emergent or fundamental? Why would consciousness not be like life? Would he be comfortable with the argument that matter is alive on a fundamental level to explain the emergence of life? Or would he say we already have a materialist explanation for life’s emergence but not for the emergence of Biological consciousness so therefore it’s reasonable to insert Fundamental consciousness as the more “simple” way to fill the void? Why would it be less simple to postulate that X = neuronal connective complexity than to posit a fundamental consciousness? Is it more likely the profoundly complex interactive connectivity of the brain or the fundamental nature of the atoms that can explain consciousness? Why would not atomic density produce consciousness if consciousness is Fundamental? Wyehwood connective complexity be necessary? Is it possible that black holes are more conscious than less dense material objects? Goff seems to agree that Biological consciousness emerged but then adds an ontological feature to matter itself and calls it necessary because he doesn’t think complex neuronal interaction is sufficient... it’s not simple, it adds something unfalsifiable without justification. It seems less simple.

The average house hold needs about 120 MBPS to operate smoothly on a daily basis. And that's before you factor in things like work from home VPNs and the fact that most people are using WIFI for service which of course slower than an ethernet connection. Most of the laptops the kids are using for virtual schooling are chromebooks which dont even have an ethernet port TO connect to.In reality; as of winter 2021; 200mbps is ideal for a family working and schooling from home. 25 MBPS download speed is ridiculous. Even 2 adults sharing an apartment really only need about 120 MBPS between the two of them assuming they are not working from home. So even in that efficient circumstance each individual still needs around 60 MBPS. Over double of what is being proposed.Even if you take into account averages; the need for bandwidth is only going to rise. It is better to get ahead. We are actually very lucky COVID19 happened in 2020 and not a decade earlier. Our telecommunications infrastructure was only BARLEY strong enough to handle what is happening right now. If this happened in 2009 or so things would not have gone this smoothly at all.

I've read Caesar's Gallic Wars.  While it's clearly a self-glorifying account, at no point does Caesar claim to be the son of an all-powerful god, or be able to raise people from the dead.  None of the claims Caesar makes about what happens fall outside the realm of possibilities.  I don't need a massive system of faith to understand how Caesar could have conquered and enslaved a bunch of tribes using a massive military.  The account of Jesus on the other hand, is full of mysticism and woo, relying heavily on previous mythologies from ancient Judea, and often not even quoting those right.  This is pure equivocation fallacy.

The Green Med's Stand on mandatory vaccines:    • With round-the-clock media coverage of coronavirus, there is a strong and growing push for Americans to widely accept the impending COVID-19 vaccine — even though the vaccine is experimental and has known safety concerns. However, the U.S. public is currently divided over whether to get the vaccine. In the latest poll from the Pew Research Center, which surveyed more than 10,000 U.S. adults in September, about half of respondents (51%) said they would definitely or probably get a coronavirus vaccine if it were available today.     • Amidst intense public pressure from government and community leaders, there are many people asking, “Will I be forced to get the COVID-19 vaccine?” There are myriad reasons why someone might choose to decline the vaccine. Among the most common are conscientious objections, religious convictions, a history of prior vaccine injury and concerns over safety, including the speed with which the vaccine is being developed and the lack of long-term safety data.     • States across the country have drafted COVID-19 vaccination plans that utilize tracking systems, outline incentives to ensure maximum uptake of the vaccine, and identify priority populations to receive the vaccine. A July 2020 Johns Hopkins report urges local and state public health agencies to explore bundling vaccination with other safety net services. “Bundling services (e.g., food security, rent assistance, free clinic services) that are already being provided to particularly vulnerable populations in the context of COVID (e.g., older adults, low-income adults, Black and minority communities) could be a way to build trust and streamline vaccine provision,” the report says.     • Such programs could ultimately result in the denial of crucial services for those who choose to opt out of the vaccine, thereby stripping individuals of any opportunity to make this medical decision for themselves. Even if the COVID-19 vaccine is not mandated, some states could choose to limit the privileges of those who can’t supply proof of vaccination. This, experts say, is a violation of human rights and constitutional rights — especially since much of the population is not at risk from harm from COVID but could easily experience harm from a fast-tracked, experimental vaccine.     • Under U.S. Supreme Court law, in order to mandate a medical intervention there must be an epidemic that imperils the entire population. According to the CDC’s own data, most people have greater than a 97 percent chance of surviving COVID. In fact, for those under 70, the survivability rate among those infected ranges from 99.5 percent to 99.9 percent. Moreover, the COVID-19 vaccine is not supposed to prevent transmission; it’s merely supposed to lessen symptoms. As such, there is no basis upon which to require the vaccine; it’s up to each person to decide how to care for their own body based on their own judgment and unique physiology.     • It is unethical and immoral to mandate an experimental vaccine that has known safety concerns and for which there is no liability. Under the PREP Act — which was passed in 2005 and invoked in March of 2020 — vaccine and drug manufacturers, government agencies, doctors and all others are 100 percent free from any and all liability (absent intentional wrongdoing) resulting from harm caused by the coronavirus vaccine. Thus, no one will bear responsibility if you or your family is harmed by the vaccine. Lastly, for those with deeply held religious beliefs (or who lead a pharmaceutical-free life), vaccination violates their convictions to abide by natural law and to walk in faith, not fear.     • Stand up for your basic human right for informed consent and to decline a medical intervention! Click below to email and tweet your governor and local lawmakers to urge them to make the COVID-19 vaccine voluntary, not mandatory. Let them know that the only one who stands to profit from the COVID-19 vaccine is the pharmaceutical industry.

You don't really need to know all the neopronouns. They're not commonly used (which is probably also why there are so many of them; there's no unified standard yet). If you happen to meet someone who does use neopronouns, that's just one set you'll need to learn. Chances of that happening, not that huge in the first place. Unless you get to know 50 nonbinary people who all just so happen to use different pronouns, there's no reason you should need to learn them all. Most people just go by he/him, she/her or they/them, and some aren't even picky (Elliot uses both he/him and they/them, so that's super convenient). I'm nonbinary and I only know two neopronouns off the top of my head and I don't know a single person who uses neopronouns. The classic pronouns remain most popular.

Part 1 of 5:The major problem with these arguments is the insistence that atheism is the same thing as rationalism.  It isn’t.  There are informed and uninformed atheists, and the informed ones are those who can show evidence for why they believe what they believe.  It’s possible to be an atheist on faith alone, which makes such a person no different from a religious believer.  Your debate should really be between informed rationalists and religious believers, and is the only valid starting point for this debate. If you compare everything the disparate branches of science have now discovered and proved which make a nonsense of the claims to be found so prevalently in the Old Testament, there are - of course - many things which  rationalists can account for which Christianity doesn’t explain or gets hopelessly wrong when it attempts to.I’m not sure where one question ends and the next begins, but the list of human phenomena you give, which you claim as being evidence for God, are all perfectly explicable via naturalism, including suffering, the perception of beauty, the propensity for humans to invent the thousands of religions which they have, the sociopolitical reasons for why one of them became more popular than the others, the illusion of free will, the undeniably-human construct of morality - which is constantly evolving - the endlessly-debunked and unproven accounts of paranormal phenomena, including near-death experiences, telepathy, encounters with ghosts, Big Foot, witches, demons, etcetera, etcetera.And before you can cite the life and death of Yeshua (the figure we later came to refer to as Jesus) you have to accept that the only evidence for this story resides in the New Testament gospels, which were written anonymously, decades after the events they describe happened, and - when read in the order in which they were actually written: Mark, Luke, Matthew and John - show an obvious development and elaboration of a legend in the making.

Those are called Omnibus Bills. They are the textbook swamp tactic to get what voters don't want.Example: The Tappan Zee Bridge connects Rockland County to Westchester County, NY. The name "Tappan Zee" is baked into the history of that area, and is a source of pride. The word combines remembrance of the Native Americans who worked with the Dutch settlers to live successfully side by side. Randomly, in a midnight omnibus bill, Governor Andrew Cuomo snuck in "Change the name of the Tappan Zee Bridge to the Governor Mario Cuomo Bridge." (His father was Governor of New York in the 80's.) The bill was obviously signed since everyone else's legislation was included in it. When the public found out, there was bipartisan outrage. The area's newspaper did numerous polls of both counties. Every time, more than 90% were opposed to changing the name of the bridge. Local Democrats and Republicans came together and sent a petition signed by hundreds of thousands of people to Albany demanding that the name remain Tappan Zee. Cuomo only addressed it once calling it a "partisan attack." Even his own party said that his father did not want a bridge or street named after him.Today, the bridge is named the "Governor Mario Cuomo Bridge." Millions of taxpayer money was paid to change the signs. To "save money," Cuomo said that most new signs only have to say "Cuomo Bridge."In summary: In the middle of the night, Governor Cuomo decided to waste millions of taxpayers dollars to change the beloved name of a major bridge to the "Cuomo Bridge." Against over 90% of the voters' wishes, he did just that in an omnibus bill.

This is often an ex-theist argument after dismissing some properties required of their beliefs. I was never a theist, so as I learned of them I already had a foundation that such arguments simply don't fit my worldview and are most often (actually always) fallacious. She's DEFINITELY in the wrong for using her fanart for profit without permission, but I also feel like these artists are doing somewhat of the same thing. I'm positive that most, if not all of these artists don't have permission to draw Belle and post it publicly. That's most definitely a form of advertisement as well, whether intentional or not, meaning the argument could be made that her likeness was used in some way to give the artists attention from the Belle Delphine community, and thus one or several of those fans are most likely going to give the artist money in return, meaning some level of profit was inadvertently made off of her likeness without her permission anyway. It's a bit of a stretch, and I could be wrong somehow as I'm pretty sure fanart is legal, but I don't think what these artists are doing is okay either. You should at least ask somebody before drawing their likeness or property, whether fanart or not. That goes for parodies as well. It's highly recommended by any lawyer or law expert that you ask for permission from the owner of the property you're parodying before you parody it.
